member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationProvisioning.Provisioner
member.summary: An application provisioning application can use the method of this class to provision and update child applications.
member.remarks: HealthVault allows certain types of application to be used to instantiate, configure, and update applications that are related to it. For example, one implementation of an application may be used and installed as many different application instances. To allow for these separate applications to be instantiated HealthVault enables a "parent" application to tell HealthVault about a new installation of the application and provide certain configuration values for it. That application will then be able access HealthVault with a unique application identifier.

member.summary: Gets the configuration information for the specified child application ID.
member.param: The connection to use to get the application information.
The unique application identifier for the child application to get the configuration information for.
member.returns: Configuration information for the specified child application.
member.exception: If is null.
If is .
If the application specified in the is not a master application, or if does not identify a child application of the calling application.
If there is an error when the HealthVault service is called.

member.param: A HealthVault connection instantiated as the provisioning application.

member.returns: The new application identifier for the new application provided by HealthVault.
member.exception: If or is null.
If , , , , , or is not specified.
If there is an error when the HealthVault service is called.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.Web.Authentication.AuthenticationTokenKeySetPair
member.summary: A keyset token pair is an explicit binding between an authentication token and the shared secret that was used to create the token. Since the token is opaque, the client doesn't really know when the token will expire by examination. However, since there is a 1:1 binding between the token and the shared secret, we can use the shared secret expiration as the token expiration.
member.remarks:
All access to an instnace of the pair must be governed through the reader/writer lock, as the token may expire at any time.
That said, any user of the WebApplicationCredential should first if verify the token is expired. If it is not, then the caller should be able to use it to make at least one call.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.Authentication.Credential
member.summary: Provides base functionality for all Microsoft HealthVault service authentication credential types. This class is abstract.
member.remarks: Credentials serve as the basis for all authentication with the Microsoft HealthVault service. Each credential class implements a specific credential type. As more credential types are required, a new credential is required for each. You should inherit from this class only if support for a new HealthVault authentication credential type is required.

member.value: An instance of .
member.remarks: The key of the dictionary is the application id of the application for which the authentication request was made. If an application ID is not present in the dictionary, then an authentication request has not been made for this application, and this method therefore returns null.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.Authentication.Credential.AuthenticateData(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Applies the shared secret to the specified data.
member.remarks:
After the initial authentication is made with the HealthVault service, all subsequent calls to the HealthVault service must have authenticated header sections. This is the method that is used to produce the hmac-data for the "auth" section.
If this method is called, then the holding connection object is trying to authenticate data, so the credential must have a shared secret.
If the credential implements its own shared secret, then this might be null.
member.param: The data to authenticate.
The starting index into the data.
The number of bytes from the start index to authenticate.
member.returns: The authenticated data is returned. If is null, String.Empty is returned.
member.exception: The parameter is null or empty.
The shared secret parameter is null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.Authentication.Credential.SharedSecret
member.summary: Gets or sets the credential's shared secret.
member.returns: An instance of representing the shared secret.
member.remarks: When a credential is used to establish an authenticated session with the Microsoft HealthVault service, it uses a shared secret to authenticate data transmissions. If the credential does not support an authenticated session, this property will be null.
member.exception: The value is set to null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.Authentication.Credential.AuthenticationMethodName
member.summary: Gets the authentication HealthVault service method name.
member.returns: A string representing the name.
member.remarks: The authorization method changes based on the credential type. Some credentials are publicly available and some must be used only by the shell.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.Web.Authentication.WebApplicationCredential
member.summary: Enables web applications to authenticate themselves, with or without the authentication context of a user.
member.remarks:
Web applications can authenticate in two modes:
First, an application can authenticate itself in the anonymous mode, that is, not in the context of a user. This mode enables application servers to communicate with the HealthVault Service as a trusted operation, but not explicitly on behalf of a user.
Secondly, an application can authenticate itself in the context of a user. This mode enables applications to communicate with the HealthVault Service both as a trusted operation and in the user context. The application can therefore explicitly perform operations as that user or as trusted operations as in the anonymous case.
The credential proves the application's identity by signing the authentication request with the application's private key. The user's context is provided by the property.

member.remarks: In order to enable a web application to authenticate with the HealthVault Service, the application must first create a . The credential consists of two explicit parameters, and implicitly utilizes the web application's private key to sign the credential XML. The sub-credential is the token received from the browser, and it represents the approval for a user to run this application for the lifetime of the token.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.Web.Authentication.WebApplicationCredential.UpdateAuthenticationResults(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Guid,Microsoft.Health.Authentication.CreateAuthenticationTokenResult})
member.summary: Inserts a dictionary of authentication results.
member.remarks:
This may be called from two primary code paths:
1) WebApplicationCredential.AuthenticateKeySetPair pair is already locked by calling thread. 2) and CreateAuthenticatedSessionToken a) the credential could be totally unintialized, including the static credentials, so there will not be a lock on the pair. But it doesn't matter since there are no contending threads to grab the pair during this call. The lock call is a slight overhead in this very rare case. b) the credential already has an existing token, including the static credentials. This call will update the credentials so it's possible the pair is being used by another thread.
This method only update results for the applicatation id for the web app.
member.param: An instance of representing the authentication results.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.Web.Authentication.WebApplicationCredential.AuthenticateData(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Applies the shared secret to the specified data.
member.remarks:
After the initial authentication is made with the HealthVault Service, all subsequent calls to the HealthVault service must have authenticated header sections. This method produces the Hash Message Authentication Code (HMAC) data for the auth section.
This method implements its own shared secret, so the SharedSecret property is null.
member.param: The data to authenticate.
The starting index into the data.
The number of bytes from the start index to authenticate.
member.returns: The authenticated data is returned.
member.exception: The parameter is null or empty.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.Package.ConnectPackage
member.summary: Methods for accessing the package APIs of HealthVault.
member.remarks: The ConnectPackage class allows applications to send user data to the user's HealthVault account, outside of the context of an ongoing interaction with the user. The application can do this by sending a data package to the HealthVault service along with the application's identifier and user specific information. The user can then go to HealthVault Shell and add the package's contents to their appropriate health record.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.Package.ConnectPackage.Create(Microsoft.Health.Web.OfflineWebApplicationConnection,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItem})
member.summary: Represents a package of user data that is created by HealthVault in order to be retrieved by a user using the HealthVault Shell.
member.remarks:
Package encryption is delegated to the .NET Crypto classes. The encryption algorithm supported by default is AES256. If TripleDES is required, the caller should create the custom Password Protected Package and call .
The answer key provided is not the actual key to the decryption. A key is derived using the answer, the salt, and the number of hash iterations (via the class). To ensure case-insensitivity, the answer is lower cased using (culturally-agnostic) prior to generating the derived key.
The algorithm used has the following parameters:
Mode = CipherMode.CBC
Padding = PaddingMode.ISO10126
The salt supplied is used as the salt to the derived key as well as the key to the supplied HMAC. The data must be appended to the hash, then encrypted and then Base64 encoded.
member.param: The application connection to HealthVault. The application ID in the connection is used when making the patient connection.
A friendly name for the patient connection which will be shown to the user when they go to HealthVault Shell to validate the connection.
A question (usually provided by the patient) to which the patient must provide the when they go to validate the connection in the HealthVault Shell.

The answer to the which the patient must use when adding the package to their record via HealthVault Shell. The answer is case-insensitive but otherwise must match exactly. Additionally, it must be at least 6 characters long.

The application specific identifier for the user. This identifier is used to uniquely identify the user in the application data storage, whereas the HealthVault person ID is used to identify the person in HealthVault.
The list of HealthRecordItems that will be encrypted and added to the package that the user will claim via HealthVault Shell.
member.returns: A token that the application must give to the patient to use when validating the connection request.
member.exception: If is null.
If , , , or any element in are null or empty.
If is less than 6 characters.
One of the items in is signed and contains streamed blobs. This is not supported.
If an error occurs when contacting HealthVault.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.Package.ConnectPackage.Create(Microsoft.Health.Package.ConnectPackageCreationParameters,System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItem})
member.summary: Represents a package of user data that is created by HealthVault in order to be retrieved by a user using the HealthVault Shell.
member.remarks:
Package encryption is delegated to the .NET Crypto classes. The encryption algorithm supported by default is AES256. If TripleDES is required, the caller should create the custom Password Protected Package and call .
The answer key provided is not the actual key to the decryption. A key is derived using the answer, the salt, and the number of hash iterations (via the class). To ensure case-insensitivity, the answer is lower cased using (culturally-agnostic) prior to generating the derived key.
The algorithm used has the following parameters:
Mode = CipherMode.CBC
Padding = PaddingMode.ISO10126
The salt supplied is used as the salt to the derived key as well as the key to the supplied HMAC. The data must be appended to the hash, then encrypted and then Base64 encoded.
member.param: The to be used while creating the connect package.
The list of HealthRecordItems that will be encrypted and added to the package that the user will claim via HealthVault Shell.
member.exception: One of the items in is signed and contains streamed blobs. This is not supported.
If an error occurs when contacting HealthVault.
member.returns: A token that the application must give to the patient to use when validating the connection request.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.Package.ConnectPackage.Create(Microsoft.Health.Web.OfflineWebApplicationConnection,System.String,System.String,System.String,Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes.PasswordProtectedPackage)
member.summary: Asks HealthVault to create a pending package for the application specified by the connection with the specified user specific parameters.
member.remarks:
The password protected package supports 2 encryption algorithms, AES256 (recommended) and TripleDES.
For AES256, the supported key size is 256 bits, the blocksize is 256 bits, the IV length is 32 bytes.
For TripleDES, the supported key size is 192 bits, the blocksize is 64 bits, the IV length is 8 bytes.
The encryption key should be derived using the answer, the salt, and the number of hash iterations. The decryption will generate this key via the class, hence, encryption should use a similar or identical process. To ensure case-insensitivity, the answer should be converted to its lower cased form using (culturally-agnostic) prior to generating the derived key.
The algorithm used has the following parameters:
Mode = CipherMode.CBC
Padding = PaddingMode.ISO10126
The salt supplied is used as the salt to the derived key as well as the key to the supplied HMAC. The salt should be at least 8 bytes long.
It is recommended that the number of hash iterations be at least 10000.
member.param: The application connection to HealthVault. The application ID in the connection is used when making the patient connection.
A friendly name for the patient connection which will be shown to the user when they go to HealthVault Shell to validate the connection.
A question (usually provided by the patient) to which the patient must provide the answer when they go to validate the connection in the HealthVault Shell.

The application specific identifier for the user. This identifier is used to uniquely identify the user in the application data storage whereas the HealthVault person ID is used to identify the person in HealthVault.

The pending connect package that the user will add to his/her record. This package's must be an encrypted and Base64 encoded blob of xml that represents a list of HealthRecordItems. This xml blob must be a sequence of elements, each wrapping the XML representation of a single HealthRecordItem. Each element may be generated by calling .
member.returns: A token that the application must give to the patient to use when validating the connection request.
member.exception: If is null.
If , , , or is null or empty.
If an error occurs when contacting HealthVault.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.Package.ConnectPackage.AllocatePackageId(Microsoft.Health.Web.OfflineWebApplicationConnection)
member.summary: Allocates a package ID within HealthVault and returns it.

remarks.para: The package ID is allocated as a place holder for information that is identifiable but not yet available through the HealthVault service. The returned package ID token should be stored or given to a patient, then used in a call to to send the package data to the HealthVault service.

The package ID is not a GUID. It uses a shorter format that is more convenient for offline delivery and manual data entry. The HealthVault service guarantees that each package ID is unique for the lifetime of the package. Once the package has been accepted by the patient using the HealthVault Shell, or explicitly deleted using the API, the package ID is deallocated and may be reused.

member.param: The HealthVault connection to use for the operation.
member.returns: A token that the application must give to the patient to use when validating the connection request.
member.exception: If is null.
If an error occurs when contacting HealthVault.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.PatientConnect.PatientConnection
member.summary: Methods for accessing the patient connection APIs of HealthVault.
member.remarks:
Some HealthVault applications maintain some of their own data storage but need a way to link their account/person identifier to a HealthVault identifier. The application can do this by calling and passing the application's identifier and some information that is specific to the user. The user can then go to HealthVault Shell and validate the connection with their appropriate health record. The application can then query for all validated connections (usually on a daily basis) by calling or which returns instances of .
Validated connect requests are removed by HealthVault after 90 days. It is advised that applications call or daily or weekly to ensure that all validated connect requests are retrieved.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.AnonymousConnection
member.summary: Represents a connection for an application to the HealthVault service for operations that require neither user authentication nor application identifier verification.
member.remarks:
You must connect to the HealthVault service to access its web methods. This class does not maintain an open connection to the service, but uses XML over HTTP to make requests and receive responses from the service. The connection only maintains the data necessary for the request.
Use an anonymous connection to access HealthVault methods that require only a valid application identifier, such as .
For operations that require authentication, use the class and its derived classes. For operations that require more specific functionality, such as querying a vocabulary list, use the class and its derived classes.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.HealthServiceConnection
member.summary: Simplifies access to the HealthVault service. This class is abstract.
member.remarks:
A connection must be made to the HealthVault service to access the web methods that the service exposes. The class does not maintain an open connection to the service. It uses XML over HTTP to make requests and receive responses from the service. The connection just maintains the data necessary to make the request.
You cannot directly instantiate this abstract class. Instead, instantiate an instance of or to communicate with the Microsoft HealthVault service.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthServiceConnection.GetServiceDefinition
member.summary: Gets information about the HealthVault service.
member.remarks:
Gets the latest information about the HealthVault service. This includes:
- The version of the service.
- The SDK assembly URLs.
- The SDK assembly versions.
- The SDK documentation URL.
- The URL to the HealthVault Shell.
- The schema definition for the HealthVault method's request and response. - The common schema definitions for types that the HealthVault methods use.
member.returns: A instance that contains the service version, SDK assemblies versions and URLs, method information, and so on.
member.exception: The HealthVault service returns an error.
One or more URL strings returned by HealthVault is invalid.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthServiceConnection.CancelAllRequests
member.summary: Cancels any pending request to HealthVault that was initiated with this connection instance and prevents any new requests from being made.
member.remarks:
Setting this property to true will cancel any requests that was started using this connection and will prevent new requests from being made. It is up to the caller to start the request on another thread. Cancelling will cause a HealthServiceRequestCancelledException to be thrown on the thread the request was executed on.
If you want to start reusing the connection set the property to false.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationConnection
member.summary: Base class that represents a connection of an application to the HealthVault service for either online or offline operations.
member.remarks:
You must connect to the HealthVault service to access its web methods. This class does not maintain an open connection to the service, but uses XML over HTTP to make requests and receive responses from the service. The connection only maintains the data necessary for the request.
For operations that require authentication, use the class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationConnection.CreateRequest(Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordAccessor,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Represents a simple wrapper around the XML request for the web service.
member.param: The record that prepopulates the request.
The name of the method to call.
The version of the method to call.
member.returns: A that wraps the XML request for the web service.
member.remarks:
This method skips the object model provided by the other methods of this class and acts as a simple wrapper around the XML request for the web service. The caller must provide the parameters in the correct format for the called method and parse the response data. The information in the parameter prepopulates the request.
By creating the request object directly rather than using the object model, you can pass parameters that are not directly exposed by the object model. Please provide feedback to us if this is the case. This also allows for request-specific parameters that are set by default when using the object model. For example, you can change the language for a specific request without affecting other requests to the HealthVault service through the same connection.
You can find a list of the HealthVault methods (including their request and response schema) at the Microsoft Live Health Lab site.
member.exception: The parameter is null.
The parameter is null or empty.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.Id
member.summary: Gets or sets the application id.
member.remarks: On retrieving an application this value will be set to the application id. When creating or updating an application, this value is ignored.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the application.
member.remarks: On updating an application configuration the name will only be updated if it is not null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.CultureSpecificNames
member.summary: Gets a dictionary of language specifiers and localized names of the application.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.PublicKeys
member.summary: Gets a collection of the public keys for the application.
member.remarks:
The public key(s) are used to uniquely and positively identify the application to the HealthVault service. The application signs its first request to HealthVault using its application private which matches the public key being passed here. When HealthVault receives that request it validates the signature using the public key.
On updating an application configuration the public key(s) will only be updated if the collection is not empty.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.OnlineBaseAuthorizations
member.summary: Gets a collection of the online base authorization rules for the application.
member.remarks:
The online base authorization rules represent the set of data that the application can access when a user is logged on.
On updating an application configuration the online base authorization rules will only be updated if the collection is not empty.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.OfflineBaseAuthorizations
member.summary: Gets a collection of the offline base authorization rules for the application.
member.remarks:
The offline base authorization rules represent the set of data that the application can access when a user is not logged on.
On updating an application configuration the offline base authorization rules will only be updated if the collection is not empty.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.CallableMethods
member.summary: Gets a collection of the HealthVault methods the application can call.
member.remarks: On updating an application configuration the callable methods will only be updated if the collection is not empty.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.VocabularyAuthorizations
member.summary: Gets a collection of authorizations to HealthVault vocabularies, that the application has access to.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.ChildVocabularyAuthorizationsCeiling
member.summary: Gets a collection of authorizations to HealthVault vocabularies. This represents the maximum authorization set that the application can grant to its child applications.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.ActionUrl
member.summary: Gets or sets the action URL for the application.
member.remarks:
The action URL is the single point of re-entry to the application from the HealthVault Shell. The implementation of the action URL must use the query string parameters to determine what the correct page is to show the user. See Microsoft.Health.Web.HealthServiceActionPage for more information.
On updating an application configuration the action URL will only be updated if the value is not null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.Description
member.summary: Gets or sets a description of the application which is shown to the user when authorizing the application to their record.
member.remarks: On updating an application configuration the description will only be updated if the value is not null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.CultureSpecificDescriptions
member.summary: Dictionary of language specifiers and localized descriptions of the application.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.AuthorizationReason
member.summary: Gets or sets the reason the application requires the base online and offline authorization rules it is requesting.
member.remarks:
The authorization reason is shown to the user when they are authorizing the application to use their health record.
On updating an application configuration the authorization reason will only be updated if the value is not null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.CultureSpecificAuthorizationReasons
member.summary: Dictionary of language specifiers and localized authorization reasons of the application.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.DomainName
member.summary: Gets or sets the domain name for the application.
member.remarks:
The domain name is used when the application calls ApplicationConnection.SendInsecureMessageFromApplication along with the specified mailbox as the sending party. For example, if the domain name of the application is "microsoft.com" and the mailbox is "example", then the user will get an email from "example@microsoft.com".
On updating an application configuration the domain name will only be updated if the value is not null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.LargeLogo
member.summary: Gets or sets the large logo for the application.
member.remarks:
The large logo is shown at various times to the user when interacting with the HealthVault Shell. The large logo must be 120x60 pixels or smaller, and is limited to 160kb in size.
On updating an application configuration the large logo will only be updated if the value is not null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.SmallLogo
member.summary: Gets or sets the small logo for the application.
member.remarks:
The small logo is shown at various times to the user when interacting with the HealthVault Shell. The small logo is limited to 40kb in size.
On updating an application configuration the small logo will only be updated if the value is not null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.PrivacyStatement
member.summary: Gets or sets the application's privacy statement.
member.remarks:
A link is provided from the HealthVault Shell to the application's privacy statement.
On updating an application configuration the privacy statement will only be updated if the value is not null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.TermsOfUse
member.summary: Gets or sets the application's terms of use.
member.remarks:
A link is provided from the HealthVault Shell to the application's terms of use.
On updating an application configuration the terms of use will only be updated if the value is not null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.DtcSuccessMessage

member.remarks: On updating an application configuration the dtc success message will only be updated if the value is not null.

member.summary: Gets or sets various configuration options that applications can use.
member.remarks:
The configuration options tell HealthVault of any special behaviors that it should allow or enforce for this application. See for more information.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.PersistentTokenTtlInSeconds
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time a user token will persist if they choose the "Keep me logged in on this computer" checkbox during HealthVault login.
member.remarks:
This value is only used if is specified in the .
On updating an application configuration the persistent token ttl will only be updated if the value is not null.
member.exception: The parameter is less than or equal to zero.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.ValidIPPrefixes
member.summary: Gets or sets the IP address masks from which the application can call HealthVault.
member.remarks: A comma separated list of IP address masks from which the application can call HealthVault. HealthVault provides some added security to applications by supporting calls that come from valid IP addresses of the application. IP addresses can be specified using a specific IP address and 32 bit mask like 192.168.0.1/32 or by specifying a subnet and mask like 192.168.0.0/16. You can have more than one IP address or mask by comma separating them.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationInfo.ClientServiceToken
member.summary: Gets the client service token.
member.remarks: The client service token is used by browser scripts to access HealthVault client services such as the vocabulary search service. The value of the client service token is set in the application configuration center.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationOptions
member.summary: Optional configuration settings for HealthVault applications.
member.remarks: The default value is None.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationOptions.None
member.summary: No optional application settings specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationOptions.PersistentTokensAllowed
member.summary: The application allows the user to stay logged in to the application across browser session.
member.remarks: This setting enables the "Keep me signed in on this computer" checkbox on the HealthVault login page.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationOptions.ApplicationAuthorizationRequired
member.summary: The application is required to notify HealthVault that a user has been authorized to use the application.
member.remarks: If this option is specified, the application must authorize HealthVault to allow the user to use the application. For example, if the application requires a subscription for use it could enable this option and then notify HealthVault when the status of the subscription has changed. In this case HealthVault will prevent the user from logging in to the application if the subscription has lapsed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationOptions.PublishApplication
member.summary: The application will be published to the application directory for users to find.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationOptions.All
member.summary: All application options are specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Health.ApplicationOptions.Default
member.summary: The default is no options specified.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.AuthenticatedConnection
member.summary: Represents an authenticated interface to the HealthVault service. Most operations performed against the service require authentication.
member.remarks:
You must connect to the HealthVault service to access its web methods. This class does not maintain an open connection to the service, but uses XML over HTTP to make requests and receive responses from the service. The connection only maintains the data necessary for the request.
An authenticated connection takes the user name and password, authenticates them against the HealthVault service, and then stores an authentication token which is then passed to the service on each subsequent request. An authenticated connection is required for accessing a person's health record.
For operations that do not require user or application authentication, use the class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.AuthenticatedConnection.Authenticate
member.summary: Logs on to the HealthVault service using the username and password.
member.remarks: It is not necessary to explicitly call this method before calling any of the methods that access the service. Those methods will call this method if the user has not already been authenticated. This method is provided as a convenience to allow for separate error handling for authorization errors.
member.exception: The caller does not have permission to connect to the requested URI or a URI to which the request is redirected.
The authorization URL specified to the constructor is not a valid URI.
The authorization was not returned in the response from the server.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.AuthenticatedConnection.Impersonate(System.Guid)
member.summary: Sets the identifier for the person being impersonated.
member.param: The unique identifier for the person to impersonate.
member.remarks:
Impersonation occurs when the authenticated person wants to make a request to the HealthVault service on behalf of another person. This should not occur in most applications.
The authenticated person must have the rights to call the requested method for the person being impersonated. If that right exists, all security processing occurs using the impersonated person's identity. If the right does not exist, the caller receives an upon the first invocation of a method that accesses the HealthVault service.
To start impersonating, call the method. To stop impersonating, call the method.
member.exception: The parameter is Guid.Empty.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.AuthenticatedConnection.StopImpersonating
member.summary: Unsets the target person identifier for all requests.
member.remarks:
All future requests will act as the authenticated person.
Note, to change the person that is being impersonated, StopImpersonating does not have to be called. can be called directly with a new target person identifier.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.AuthorizationRule
member.summary: This class defines an authorization rule in the HealthVault service.
member.remarks:
Authorization rules are applied to authorized records to state what permissions the person or group being authorized has on the data in that record. See the HealthVault Developer's Guide for more information on how authorization works in HealthVault.
This rule does not necessarily represent a rule that is present on the server. It can be used to generate the necessary XML when using the Shell pages to authorize records.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.DateRangeSetDefinition
member.summary: Defines a set of health record items for authorization purposes whose effective date falls within a specified range.
member.remarks: Permissions on data in a person's health records are always included in an authorization set (whether implicitly via their type or effective date, or explicitly by setting the system set.) This class serves as a set of health record items that have effective dates falling within the specified range. Other types of authorization sets include .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.DateRangeSetDefinition.#ctor(System.DateTime,System.DateTime)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class with the specified minimum and maximum dates.
member.param: The minimum effective date of the health record items included in the set.
The maximum effective date of health record items included in the set.
member.remarks: All dates and times are considered to be in UTC time. The calling application must do any conversion from local time.
member.exception: The parameter is greater than the parameter.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.DateRangeSetDefinition.GetXml
member.summary: Gets the XML representation of the set.
member.returns: The XML representation of the set as a string.
member.remarks: The XML representation adheres to the schema required by the HealthVault methods.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.DateRangeSetDefinition.DateMin
member.summary: Gets the minimum effective date of the health record items in this set.
member.value: A DateTime value in UTC.
member.remarks: The calling application is responsible for changing any local times to UTC.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.DateRangeSetDefinition.DateMax
member.summary: Gets the maximum effective date of the health record items in this set.
member.value: A DateTime value in UTC.
member.remarks: The calling application is responsible for changing any local times to UTC time.

member.remarks: This property corresponds to the "HashAlgorithmName" configuration value. The value defaults to "SHA256".

member.remarks: This property corresponds to the "SignatureHashAlgorithmName" configuration value. The value defaults to "SHA1".

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.DefaultRequestTimeout
member.summary: Gets the request timeout in seconds.
member.remarks: This value is used to set the property when making the request to HealthVault. The timeout is the number of seconds that a request will wait for a response from HealtVault. If the method response is not returned within the time-out period the request will throw a with the Status property set to . This property corresponds to the "defaultRequestTimeout" configuration value. The value defaults to 30 seconds.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.DefaultRequestTimeToLive
member.summary: Gets the request time to live in seconds.
member.remarks: This property defines the "msg-ttl" in the HealthVault request header XML. It determines how long the same XML can be used before HealthVault determines the request invalid. This property corresponds to the "defaultRequestTimeToLive" configuration value. The value defaults to 1800 seconds.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.RetryOnInternal500Count
member.summary: Gets the number of retries the .NET APIs will make when getting an internal error response (error 500) from HealthVault.
member.remarks: This property corresponds to the "RequestRetryOnInternal500" configuration value. The value defaults to 2.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.RetryOnInternal500SleepSeconds
member.summary: Gets the sleep duration in seconds between retries due to HealthVault returning an internal error (error 500).
member.remarks: This property corresponds to the "RequestRetryOnInternal500SleepSeconds" configuration value. The value defaults to 1 second.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.RequestCompressionThreshold
member.summary: Gets the size in kilobytes above which requests will be compressed.
member.remarks: This property corresponds to the "requestCompressionThreshold" configuration value. The value defaults to 1KB.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.RequestCompressionMethod
member.summary: Gets the method used to compress requests.
member.remarks: This property corresponds to the "requestCompressionMethod" configuration value. The value defaults is to not compress requests.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.ResponseCompressionMethods
member.summary: Gets the application's supported compression methods that can be sent back from HealtVault during a method response.
member.remarks: This property corresponds to the "responseCompressionMethods" configuration value. The value defaults to not compress responses.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.InlineBlobHashBlockSize
member.summary: Gets the size in bytes of the block used to hash inlined BLOB data.
member.remarks: This property corresponds to the "defaultInlineBlobHashBlockSize" configuration value. The value defaults to 2MB.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.SupportedTypeVersions
member.summary: Gets the type version identifiers of types supported by this application.
member.remarks: Although most applications don't need this configuration setting, if an application calls or makes any query to HealthVault that doesn't specify the type identifier in the filter, this configuration setting will tell HealthVault the format of the type to reply with. For example, if a web application has two servers and makes a call to GetItem for EncounterV1 and the application authorization is set to the EncounterV1 format then the application will get EncounterV1 instances back even if the record contains Encounter v2 instances. Now the application wants to upgrade to Encounter v2 without having application down-time. In order to do this, one of the application servers must be updated to Encounter v2 while the other still works with EncounterV1. If we were to rely solely on application authorization one of the servers would be broken during the upgrade. However, by using this configuration value to specify what type version the server supports (rather than the application), then both servers can continue to work while the application is upgraded.
member.exception: If the configuration contains the name of a type that is not registered as a type handler in .

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthApplicationConfiguration.UseLegacyTypeVersionSupport
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether or not legacy type versioning support should be used.
member.remarks: Type versions support was initially determined by an applications base authorizations and/or the . Some of these behaviors were unexpected which led to changes to automatically put the and into the automatically for developers. This exhibits the expected behavior for most applications. However, in some rare cases applications may need to revert back to the original behavior. When this property returns true the original behavior will be observed. If false, the new behavior will be observed. This property defaults to false and can be changed in the web.config file "UseLegacyTypeVersionSupport" setting.

member.summary: Start the authorization process.
member.remarks: Starts the authorization process by opening an authorization page in the user's default browser. After this call, the application is responsible for waiting until the authorization process is completed before continuing. A typical implementation will create a UI element that allows the user to indicate that authorization is complete.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.HealthClientAuthorizedConnection
member.summary: Represents an authorized connection between a HealthVault client application and the HealthVault service.
member.remarks: HealthClientAuthorizedConnection is a connection used by a HealthVault client application. The connection is authenticated using an application certificate in the user store, and does not require an authenticated user. The connection is only valid for instances, and each instance must be authorized using the HealthVault Shell service.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.Web.OfflineWebApplicationConnection
member.summary: Represents a connection for an application to HealthVault for operations that are performed when a user is offline using the permissions granted by the user to the application.
member.remarks:
A connection must be made to HealthVault to access the Web methods that the service exposes. This class does not maintain an open connection to the service. It uses XML over HTTP to to make requests and receive responses from the service. The connection just maintains the data necessary to make the request.
For operations that require the user to be online, use the class.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordAccessor
member.summary: Represents the API set used to access a health record for an individual.
member.remarks: A HealthRecordAccessor represents a person's view of a health record. This view can vary based upon the access rights the person has to the record. More than one person might have access to the same record but have different views. For instance, a husband might have a HealthRecordAccessor instance for himself and another for his wife's health record to which she granted him access.

member.summary: Sends an insecure message originating from the application to custodians of the health record.
member.param: If true, HealthVault will only send the message to custodians with validated e-mail addresses. If false, the message will be sent even if the custodians' addresses have not been validated.

An application specified mailbox name that's sending the message. The mailbox name is appended to the application's domain name to form the From email address of the message. This parameter should only contain the characters before the @ symbol of the email address.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordAccessor.GetValidGroupMembership(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Guid})
member.summary: Gets valid group memberships for a record.
member.remarks:
Group membership thing types allow an application to signify that the record belongs to an application defined group. A record in the group may be eligible for special programs offered by other applications, for example. Applications then need a away to query for valid group memberships.
Valid group memberships are those memberships which are not expired, and whose last updating application is authorized by the the last updating person to read and delete the membership.
member.param: A collection of unique application identifiers for which to search for group memberships. For a null or empty application identifier list, return all valid group memberships for the record. Otherwise, return only those group memberships last updated by one of the supplied application identifiers.
member.returns: A List of HealthRecordItems representing the valid group memberships.
member.exception: If an error occurs while contacting the HealthVault service.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordFilter.MaxItemsReturned
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of health record items to return.
member.remarks: The default value returns all items that match the filter.
member.exception: The is set to less than zero.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordFilter.MaxFullItemsReturnedPerRequest
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of full health record items returned per request to HealthVault.
member.remarks: By default HealthVault will only return a certain number of "full" health record items for any query. It then returns the "keys" for the remaining items that matched the query which can then be queried for by ID. automatically manages this paging for you. However, if you want further control over the count of full items retrieved on each request, can be set to optimize for smaller sets of data. For example, let's say the data being retrieved is being displayed in a GridView and the results are shown 10 items per page. Rather than get the default number of full things, you can request 10 full items per request. Then only if the user clicks to the second page would you need to get the next 10 items.
member.exception: The is set to less than zero.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordFilter.View

member.remarks: The default view retrieves the "Core" and data sections ("Xml").
member.exception: The is null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordFilter.ItemIds
member.summary: Gets or sets the ids identifying health record items for the search filter.
member.remarks: Each specified ID is AND'd with any other filter parameter. The filter limits the search to the specified health record items. It is illegal to specify both ItemIds and ItemKeys in a single filter.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordFilter.ItemKeys
member.summary: Gets or sets the keys uniquely identifying health record items for the search filter.
member.remarks: Each specified ItemKey is AND'd with any other filter parameter. The filter limits the search to the specified health record items. It is illegal to specify more than one of ItemIds, ClientItemIds or ItemKeys in a single filter.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordFilter.ClientItemIds
member.summary: Gets or sets the client assigned IDs identifying health record items for the search filter.
member.remarks: Each specified ID is AND'd with any other filter parameter. The filter limits the search to the specified health record items. It is illegal to specify more than one of ItemIds, ClientItemIds or ItemKeys in a single filter.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordFilter.TypeIds
member.summary: Gets a collection of the unique item type identifiers to search for.
member.remarks: Each health record item is associated with a type through a type identifier. If set, these values are combined in an OR operation. The group is then combined in an AND operation with any other filter value in the search for matching health record items. This AND operation excludes ItemId as a filter value, because ItemId results are obtained by an OR operation. To add a type ID, use the Add method of the returned collection.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordFilter.States

member.value:
The set of flags. If not specified, health record items with state
are returned.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordInfo
member.summary: Represents the APIs and information about a health record for an individual.
member.remarks: A HealthRecordInfo represents a person's view of a health record and information about the health record such as the state, name, date of expiration, and so on. This view may vary based upon the access rights the person has to the record and multiple people may have access to the same record but have different views. For instance, a husband may have a HealthRecordInfo instance for himself and another for his wife's health record which she shared with him.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItem
member.summary: Represents a health record item.
member.remarks:
A health record item is a single piece of data in a health record that is accessible through the HealthVault service. Examples of health record items include a blood pressure measurement, an exercise session, or an insurance claim.
Health record items are typed and have XML data that adheres to the schema for the type.

Signing failed. See the inner exception. The inner exception may be one of the following: An is thrown because there is a load or parse error loading the xsl. A CryptographicException is thrown because the nodelist from the xsl does not contain an object. A is thrown because signingCertificate.PrivateKey is not an RSA or DSA key, or is unreadable. A is thrown because signingCertificate.PrivateKey is not a DSA or RSA object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItem.IsSignatureValid
member.summary: Checks if the health record item's signature is valid.
member.remarks:
Verifies that the signature on the item is valid for the XML representation of the item as retrieved from the HealthVault service.
This method will always verify against the underlying XML of this item as returned from the service, even if local modifications are made to the item. In the case of new items that have not yet been created in the HealthVault service, this method validates the signature against the XML of the item at the time of signing.
For more information about XML digital signatures see: .
member.returns: true if the signature is valid against the XML representation of the item returned from the service, or for new items, if the signature is valid against the XML of the item at the time the item was signed. Returns false if the signature could not be validated.
member.exception: The signature could not be validated because the is not signed.

Signature validation failed becaue either the of this item is unknown and cannot be validated, or the integrity of the signature could not be verified in which case the inner exception contains details on the reasons why. The inner exception is , thrown because of one of: The SignatureAlgorithm property of the public key in the signature does not match the SignatureMethod property. The signature description could not be created. The hash algorithm could not be created.

member.exception: Certificate validation failed. There may be an inner exception is , thrown because of: The certificate is unreadable. If there is no inner exception, there will be a string with info about the certificate and the error.
The certificate could not be validated because the is not signed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItem.GetBlobStore(Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordAccessor)
member.summary: Gets the BLOB store for this health record item.
member.param: The that any BLOB data will be written to. This parameter may be null if only read access is required or the BLOB data to be written is for a .
member.remarks:
This method replaces the previous OtherData property. All binary data is now created, updated, and retrieved through instance associated with the .
GetBlobStore will return an empty store on an existing if is not specified when retrieving the item. In this case it is possible to overwrite or remove existing Blobs in the instance stored in HealthVault by using the same name as the existing Blob. It is recommended that if you are going to be manipulating Blobs in the BlobStore, that you specify when retrieving the item.
member.returns: A instance related to this health record item.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItem.GetSizeInBytes
member.summary: Gets the size of the health record item which will be added to the quota used in the person's health record.
member.remarks: This size may be used to determine if there is sufficient room left in the person's health record. It is recommended that this be used only for large items that may cause the person to exceed their quota. This measurement is an approximation. The HealthVault service may evaluate the item to have slightly more or fewer bytes depending on how the white space is transformed between the client and server. The person's health record quota usage may also change on the HealthVault service due to data being added by other applications.
member.returns: The size in bytes of the health record item.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItem.Serialize
member.summary: Gets the XML representation of the item for serialization.
member.remarks:
There are two ways to obtain an XML representation of the item. GetItemXml() returns only the XML for the type-specific information of the item. Serialize() returns the full XML.
Use GetItemXml() if you want to save the XML representation to pass to the HealthVault platform for a new or update operation. Use Serialize if you want to serialize and deserialize the item and have the deserialized item be identical to the serialized one.
member.returns: A string containing the XML representation of the item.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemCollection.Sort(System.Comparison{Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItem})
member.summary: Sorts the HealthRecordItems in the collection using the specified comparison method.
member.param: The comparison method to use when sorting the collection.
member.remarks:
This method will cause all results to be retrieved from HealthVault.
When a query results in many matches, HealthVault will return a fixed number of "full" results (all data requested is returned) and the remaining matches as "partial" (only identifying information is returned). HealthRecordItemCollection automatically retrieves the full information for the partial results as the collection gets enumerated. In order to sort the results, HealthRecordItemCollection must retrieve the full set of data for all the results. This may cause several requests to HealthVault to retrieve all the data.
member.exception: is null.
The implementation of caused an error during the sort. For example, might not return 0 when comparing an item with itself.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemCollection.Sort(System.Collections.Generic.IComparer{Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItem})
member.summary: Sorts the HealthRecordItems in the collection using the specified comparer.
member.param: The implementation to use when comparing elements, or null to use the defalt comparer .
member.remarks:
This method will cause all result to be retrieved from HealthVault.
When a query results in many matches, HealthVault will return a fixed number of "full" results (all data requested is returned) and the remaining matches as "partial" (only identifying information is returned). HealthRecordItemCollection automatically pages down the full information for the partial results as the collection gets enumerated. In order to sort the results, HealthRecordItemCollection must retrieve the full set of data for all the results. This may cause several requests to HealthVault to retrieve all the data.
member.exception: is null, and the default comparer cannot find implementation of the generic interface.
The implementation of caused an error during the sort. For example, might not return 0 when comparing an item with itself.

member.summary: Advances the enumerator to the next element of the collection.
member.returns: true if the enumerator was successfully advanced to the next element; false if the enumerator has passed the end of the collection.
member.remarks:
After an enumerator is created or after the method is called, an enumerator is positioned before the first element of the collection, and the first call to the method moves the enumerator over the first element of the collection.
If passes the end of the collection, the enumerator is positioned after the last element in the collection and returns false. When the enumerator is at this position, subsequent calls to also return false until is called.
An enumerator remains valid as long as the collection remains unchanged. If changes are made to the collection, such as adding, modifying, or deleting elements, the enumerator is irrecoverably invalidated and the next call to or throws an .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemDataTable.GetData(Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordAccessor,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Fills in the data table with data from the HealthVault service starting at the specific index for the count specified.
member.param: The health record to get the data from.
The index to start retrieving full data from HealthVault.
The count of full items to retrieve.
member.remarks:
This method makes a web-method call to the HealthVault service.
The default implementation fills the data with complete information for all items matching the filter. If the is being bound to a HealthServiceDataGrid or other such control that supports paging, this may not be the desired result as many calls to HealthVault may be required to fetch all the data. This overload of GetData allows the caller to specify the index and the count of the full items to retrieve to match the page that is currently visible. The will be filled with empty values except for the rows specified.
member.exception: An error occurred while accessing the HealthVault service.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension
member.summary: Represents an extension to a health record item.
member.remarks:
Applications can augment the HealthVault defined data for a health record item type with application or vendor specific data by implementing item extensions.
Applications that implement a health record item extension should derive from this class and register their extension by calling . Whenever the HealthVault SDK reads an extension with the specified extension source an instance of the derived HealthRecordItemExtension will be created and it's method will be called to populate the data of the class from the web-service XML. Common portions of the item extension data will be parsed by the base class and exposed as properties.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs a health record item extension for the specified source.
member.param: The source identifier for the extension. This is used to uniquely identify the extension data.
member.exception: If is null or empty.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor used when creating an instance for XML deserialization.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.ParseXml(System.Xml.XPath.XPathNavigator)
member.summary: Parses the common portions of the extension data.
member.param: The XML to get the extension data from.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.ParseXml(System.Xml.XPath.IXPathNavigable)
member.summary: Populates the extension data from the specified XML.
member.param: The XML to retrieve the extension data from. Note, this may be an .
member.remarks:
Derived classes should override this method to parse the extension XML and populate class members with the data. The common extension attributes are handled by the base class before this method is called.
The default implementation of this method does nothing.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.WriteExtensionXml(System.Xml.XmlWriter)
member.summary: Writes the extension data to the specified writer.
member.param: The writer to write the extension XML to.
member.exception: If is null or empty.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.WriteXml(System.Xml.XmlWriter)
member.summary: Writes the data portion of the extension to the specified XML writer.
member.param: The XML writer to write the data portion of the extension to.
member.remarks:
Derived classes should override this method to add extension specific data to the extension XML for the item. Note, the base class handles writing the extension node and it's attributes to the writer. The derived class implementation should only write the inner nodes of the extension.
The base implementation writes the contents of the to the writer and should not be called by the derived class.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.Source
member.summary: Gets or sets the extension source identifier.
member.remarks: The source is used to identify the extension. To register a class as a handler for a specific extension source see .
member.exception: If is null or empty.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.Version
member.summary: Gets or sets the version of the extension.
member.remarks: The version is optional and will be ignored if set to null.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.Logo
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL to a logo for display use with the extension.
member.remarks:
The logo is optional and will be ignored if set to null.
In some applications a generic view of the health record item will be shown. If a logo is provided on an extension those applications can embed the logo in the user interface to show the user that there is additional data. It can also be used along with the to provide a link to the extension data.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.Transform
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL to an XSL transform which can transform the XML of the extension into HTML suitable for display in a small form or popup.
member.remarks:
The transform is optional and will be ignored if set to null.
In some applications a generic view of the health record item will be shown. In such applications the extension data can be rendered as HTML using the specified transform.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordItemExtension.ExtensionData
member.summary: Gets the extension data for the extension.
member.remarks: To modify the extension attributes use the other properties of this class. To modify the extension data manipulate the returned XML document unless a derived type is available, in which case you should use the properties and method of the derived type to manipulate the data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordSearcher.GetTransformedItems(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the health record items specified by the and runs them through the specified transform.
member.param: A URL to a transform to run on the resulting XML. This can be a fully-qualified URL or the name of one of the standard XSLs provided by the HealthVault system.
member.returns: The string resulting from performing the specified transform on the XML representation of the items.
member.remarks:
This method accesses the HealthVault service across the network.
Any call to HealthVault may specify a transform to be run on the response XML. The transform can be specified as a XSL fragment or a well-known transform tag provided by the HealthVault service. If a XSL fragment is specified, it gets compiled and cached on the server.
A final-xsl is useful when you want to convert the result from XML to HTML so that you can display the result directly in a web page. You may also use it to generate other data formats like CCR, CCD, CSV, RSS, etc.
Transform fragments cannot contain embedded script. The following set of parameters are passed to all final-xsl transforms:
currentDateTimeUtc - the date and time just before the transform started executing
requestingApplicationName - the name of the application that made the request to HealthVault.
countryCode - the ISO 3166 country code from the request.
languageCode - the ISO 639-1 language code from the request.
personName - the name of the person making the request.
recordName - if the request identified a HealthVault record to be used, this parameter contains the name of that record.
member.exception: The parameter is null or empty.
does not contain the XML section in the view.
There is a failure retrieving the items. -or- No filters have been specified.

member.summary: Generates the XML for the parameters for the "GetThings" request.
member.returns: An XML string defining the parameters for the "GetThings" call.
member.exception: No filters have been specified.

member.summary: Gets the names of the transforms to apply to the resulting XML data section.
member.remarks: The name of the transform refers to the format of the data to which the transform converts the XML data. For example, "rss" converts the XML data into RSS format. Note, all formats to which the data can be converted are legal XML documents (RSS, XHTML, and so on). A list of the valid transform names is available in the HealthVault Developer's Guide.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordView.TypeVersionFormat
member.summary: Gets a collection of the version IDs for the types in which the results should be formatted.
member.remarks: When a type gets versioned, HealthVault will retrieve instances of multiple versions even when only one type is specified in the request filter. By default HealthVault will map the XML of the instance to the version supported by the application based on the base authorization XML specified in the configuration of the application in HealthVault. However, if multiple versions are supported by the application, it can use this property to state the version format to use when writing out the instance XML. For example, when querying for medications, HealthVault will retrieve medications of both version one and two schemas. If an application only supports version one of the medication schema, then HealthVault will automatically map version two instances down to the version one schema. However, if the application supports both version one and two by declaring both type IDs in the applications configuration, then version one instances will be returned using the version one schema, and version two instances will be returned using the version two schema. If this application wants to retrieve all instances using a common schema (say version two), then it would specify the version two type ID in this parameter and all instances will be mapped to version two of the medication schema before being returned. Be careful when adding to this collection. If you are not specifying any and the Microsoft.Health.ItemTypes namespace doesn't contain a class for parsing the type version you specify, you will get a instance rather than the type specific class instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordView.BlobNames
member.summary: Gets a collection representing the names of the BLOBs to return for the item(s).
member.remarks: If no BLOB names are specified, all BLOBs will be returned.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordView.BlobFormat
member.summary: Gets the format of the BLOB that should be returned.
member.remarks: Defaults to .Unknown.

member.remarks: When an application performs a write action on an item the audit is stamped with the applications unique identifier. In the case of master/child applications, or SODA applications, the is the identifier of the child or installation of the application. The is the application identifier for the root of the configuration for that application. In the case of master/child applications, this is the application identifier of the master. For SODA applications, this is the application identifier for the root configuration of the application.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Health.HealthServiceLocation
member.summary: Provides methods that retrieve URLs of important locations for the HealthVault service.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthServiceLocation.GetHealthServiceShellUrl(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs a URL to be redirected to via the HealthVault service Shell URL redirector, given the specified location.
member.param:
A known constant indicating the internal HealthVault service Shell location to redirect to.
Locations and their parameters include:
APPAUTH - allows the user to select and authorize a health record for use with the specified application.
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
ismra - the application can use multiple records for the same user at one time.
extrecordid - record identifier.
onopt# - A sequence of online optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
offopt# - A sequence of offline optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
APPCONTENT - display application specific content such as privacy statement or terms of use.
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
target - used to specify content to display. The same supported values as property.
APPREDIRECT - Redirect user to a HealthVault application.
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the destination application.
refappid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the referring application.
target - string used as the "target" parameter when user browser is redirected to the destination application's action-url.
targetqs - string used as the "targetqs" parameter when user browser is redirected to the destination application's action-url
APPSIGNOUT - Signs the user out of HealthVault.
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
AUTH - the sign-in page
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
ismra - the application can use multiple records for the same user at one time.
forceappauth - force redirect to APPAUTH target once user is authenticated.
onopt# - A sequence of online optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
offopt# - A sequence of offline optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
CREATEACCOUNT - Allows the user to create a new HealthVault account.
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
ismra - the application can use multiple records for the same user at one time.
onopt# - A sequence of online optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
offopt# - A sequence of offline optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
nsi - no sign in page. The sign in page (where the user enters an email address) is bypassed if set to 1.
CREATEAPPLICATION - Allows a SODA master application to create a new client application instance.
publickey - the public key of the new client application instance. The key must be an X509 certificate that is base64 encoded.
appid - the GUID that uniquely identifies the SODA master application. The new application instance will be a child of this master application.
instanceid - the GUID that will be assigned to the client application. This ID must be unique for every application instance.
instancename - A string that identifies the device the new application instance will run on, such as the computer name.
CREATERECORD - Allows the user to create a new HealthVault record.
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
ismra - the application can use multiple records for the same user at one time.
onopt# - A sequence of online optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
offopt# - A sequence of offline optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
HELP - The HealthVault help page.
topicid - optional. If not specified the table of contents will be shown.
faq - HealthVault Frequently Asked Questions
HelpDirectory - Main HealthVault help page
PrivacyPolicy - HealthVault privacy policy
Service Agreement - HealthVault Service Agreement
CodeofConduct - HealthVault Code of Conduct
The shell does not provide a mechanism to return to the application from the account management page, so it is good practice to open the page in a new browser window.
MANAGEACCOUNT - Takes the user to a page to manage their account profile.
The shell does not provide a mechanism to return to the application from the account management page, so it is good practice to open the page in a new browser window.
RECONCILE - A page that allows a HealthVault user to review the individual data elements within a CCR or CCD item and transform/merge them into individual HealthVault items in their record.
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
extrecordid - record identifier.
thingid - CCR/CCD item identifier.
RECORDLIST - A page that lists all records of a HealthVault user.
appid - optional, the page displays only records which the specified application is authorized to access.
SHAREDAPPDETAILS - Allows the user to manage application authorization for a HealthVault record.
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
extrecordid - record identifier.
The shell does not provide a mechanism to return to the application from the account management page, so it is good practice to open the page in a new browser window.
SHARERECORD - Allows the user to share a record that they are a custodian of to another HealthVault account.
appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
extrecordid - record identifier.
VIEWITEMS - Allows a HealthVault user to view all of the items of the specified data type in the their record.
typeid - data type identifier.
additem - flag to show the new item dialog for the data type.
extrecordid - record identifier.
member.remarks: The is passed as the target parameter value to the redirector URL.
member.returns: The constructed URL.
member.exception: The specific target location constructs an improper URL.

appid - A GUID that uniquely identifies the application.
ismra - the application can use multiple records for the same user at one time.
forceappauth - force redirect to APPAUTH target once user is authenticated.

offopt# - A sequence of offline optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
CREATEACCOUNT - Allows the user to create a new HealthVault account.

ismra - the application can use multiple records for the same user at one time.

offopt# - A sequence of offline optional authorization rule names identifying which rules to present. The sequence begins with 1.
nsi - no sign in page. The sign in page (where the user enters an email address) is bypassed if set to 1.
CREATEAPPLICATION - Allows a SODA master application to create a new client application instance.
publickey - the public key of the new client application instance. The key must be an X509 certificate that is base64 encoded.
appid - the GUID that uniquely identifies the SODA master application. The new application instance will be a child of this master application.
instanceid - the GUID that will be assigned to the client application. This ID must be unique for every application instance.
instancename - A string that identifies the device the new application instance will run on, such as the computer name.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Health.HealthVaultPlatform.GetValidGroupMembership(Microsoft.Health.ApplicationConnection,Microsoft.Health.HealthRecordAccessor,System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Guid})
member.summary: Gets valid group memberships for a record.
member.remarks:
Group membership thing types allow an application to signify that the record belongs to an application defined group. A record in the group may be eligible for special programs offered by other applications, for example. Applications then need a away to query for valid group memberships.
Valid group memberships are those memberships which are not expired, and whose last updating application is authorized by the the last updating person to read and delete the membership.
member.param: The connection to use to access the data.
The record to use.

A collection of unique application identifiers for which to search for group memberships. For a null or empty application identifier list, return all valid group memberships for the record. Otherwise, return only those group memberships last updated by one of the supplied application identifiers.
member.returns: A List of HealthRecordItems representing the valid group memberships.
member.exception: If an error occurs while contacting the HealthVault service.
